tasks.task: Provide advice on managing bloat in livestock during spring
subtasks: Discuss the prevalence and concerns of bloat in pastures with high clover and looses content.
Mention the limitations of available bloat control products, such as the discontinued clopid capsules and the label claim for rumensin in loose licks.
Suggest rotating stock onto alternative feeds or postponing grazing until clover and looses have flowered to reduce bloat risk.
Advise on gradual stock introduction to risky pastures, limiting initial access time and monitoring animals for signs of distress.
Recommend allowing animals to graze for later parts of the day when bloat risk may be lower, such as after plants have had time to photosensitize.
Suggest using bloat oil products in livestock feed to help prevent bloat, considering the abundant surface water in pastures.
Emphasize the importance of preventative vaccination for pulpit kidney, such as with five-in-one products, and the necessity of regular boosters every six to eight weeks.
Encourage individuals to consult local veterinarians or agricultural extension teams for further assistance and support in managing bloat risks.
